intro: Streptanthus glandulosus subsp. albidus, commonly known as the white-stemmed whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to western North America. It is characterized by its glandular-hairy stems and small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important plants like mustard and cabbage. Its ecological role includes providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a host plant for certain insects.
